Fields.DialogueText: I see a wreck to windward and a lofty ship to lee... a-sailing down along the coasts of High Barbary!
You're in fine spirits, Enterprise.
Yessir! Bound for the coast of Brazil, on a fine day like this, with engines running smooth and everything shipshape... what more could a Belle want?
I've been hearing sea shanties hummed throughout the entire ship. The very engines seem to hum with them.
Sea shanties are one of the things passed down to me by my predecessors! They're a piece of my legacy!
Did you... teach them to the crew?
A few, Captain! But I've found I don't really need to, on a fine day like this, when I'm singing... the crew just pick them up.
That's odd.
Nothing unusual about it. Sailors like music. Ah, the music of Brazil is beautiful... and the food... you'll have to bring me some good feijoada when we make port in Natal!
Feijoada?
It's a sort of stew, a Portuguese dish. I first got a taste of it back on my shakedown cruise... Feijoada and cachaça, sugarcane liquor... you'll never taste anything better, Captain.

Fields.MenuText: I'll make sure some of both are brought onboard for you.
You're thinking about food at a time like this? We're at war.
I know what it is. I just didn't think it would be your sort of dish.

Fields.DialogueText: Thank you, Captain! You're a cool cat.
And feijoada keeps my engines running, Captain! Well... metaphorically, at least!
What, 'cause I'm American? It's good food, Captain!
But I don't think we'll make to Natal on time, Captain. My RDF just pinged some bandit sneaking up on us...
There! It's a Morgana!
Oh, she's going to regret crossing paths with me!
@BATTLE
I'm glad to be away from that rendezvous. Did you learn anything useful?
What's put such a sour look on your face? Hyūga give you some grief?
... No. She's just good at making her feelings clear.
What are you talking about?
She's old. Old for a ship, at least, and traditional. She'd prefer aircraft carriers stay where they belong... in the back lines, not gallivanting off to South America to chase Morganas.
Ah.
I don't mind strong opinions, and I'm always willing to take suggestions. But that Hyūga... she just wanted to put me in my place.

Fields.MenuText: I almost feel bad for her. If she's unsettled by unconventional methods, this really isn't her war.
I don't think I'd want to get involved in a conflict of personality between two warships.
Well... she has a point, sometimes. You are a bit reckless.

Fields.DialogueText: Exactly! Though... the Fleet needs every ship we can get.
Hah, that's probably wise, Cap.
And she's a lumbering old elephant from another age! I would take reckless over outdated, Captain.
Hah, well, Hyūga's crew didn't have much to say, but there was a passenger onboard to be passed along to us.
Oh? Who is it?
Some American photographer. She's been travelling around, photographing the efforts of the Neutrality Fleet. She's doing some work on wartime propaganda for the American government.
And she wants to photograph me?
Apparently so. She wants to capture you in action, and any other American Belles she can meet. Do you mind if she travels with us for a little while?
Of course not! That's... odd, but highly flattering! We can give her the sort of action that will thrill the American public.
I'm sure you will.
*ALARM*
Looks like we'll be showing that photographer a bit of action earlier than expected.
@BATTLE
Enterprise! Tell me, am I delusional, or are there fewer cats than usual onboard?
You're not delusional, Captain. I gave one of Lu's litter to Hyūga.
I thought you didn't like her.
It's bad luck to set to sea without a cat, Captain. I figure in these times, with the Morgana fleet getting stronger every day... even Hyūga needs some luck.

Fields.MenuText: That's very generous of you, Enterprise.
I'll be glad to have one fewer cat under my feet.
Aren't you worried she'll take poor care of the cat?

Fields.DialogueText: It's just common courtesy! I may not like her, but we're all together in this fight.
Don't say that. You know you like them!
Oh, no, I know she won't. Besides, no smart crew will abuse a cat. Cats are useful.
Besides luck, it will help her cut down on her rat population... and you know, old ships like that, it's easier for the rats to hide up in crevices.
Nobody taught you to respect your elders, did they?
I give respect to those who earn it, not snide battleships who wouldn't know a floatplane from a fighter plane.
But speaking of vermin, I think we've got another Morgana trying to sneak up behind us, Captain! It will be good to get into a proper fight.
@BATTLE
Captain, can we throw Miss Adele overboard?
The photographer? I think Washington might be upset if we offed their propaganda artists.
Augh!
Dare I ask?
The woman is completely impractical. She's looking for pin-up girls, not Belles!
What?
Not in the literal sense, but... ugh. She wants something to boost the US Navy morale, and engage the folks back at home...
She wants to turn the Belles into dashing silver-screen heroines.
Well... you did say you were in a movie once.
As a ship, Captain! Not as some dreamy-eyed ingenue! If she wants to show the strength of our navies, she has ample opportunity.
Instead, she wants to slather me in paste and pose me looking starry-eyed and stupid against a mast.

Fields.MenuText: If they want to turn you into propaganda, they should showcase your strength.
You are quite pretty. Perhaps she just wants to show your softer side.
She's the artist, not you. I remember you saying you would do anything for your country.

Fields.DialogueText: Like I said! But no, what will really make Americans want to go out and collect scrap and grow victory gardens is an over-dressed, paint-smothered me, apparently.
She can shove her softer side up her... augh!
I would! I will do my duty! My duty is not to be a pin-up girl!
If she wants a Belle to pose and look pretty, there are plenty of us who are good at it! Just not me.
Hah, well, I'm afraid you still can't throw her overboard.
Damn. Well, my RDF is picking up a Morgana moving toward us. At least we can get something worthwhile done today...
@BATTLE
Captain! How was your excursion to Natal? Did you pick me up some feijoada?
I'm afraid not, and unfortunately, we won't be able to stay in port long.
Why not? What's happened? We were supposed to take on the new squadron of fighters, and we've got to give them a little time to drill before throwing them into the fire.
I remember you saying trial by fire is the best sort of trial. It will have to do for now.
Are you up to speed on "volunteer fleets?"
I guess that depends on what you mean by "up to speed." They're civilian ships, right?
Correct, though I think some of their crews might argue the point.
There are a lot of people out there who want to fight back against the Morganas, but haven't been allowed to serve in regular navies.
Whether because of age or gender or criminal records. Whatever.
And, at the same time, there are... well, let's say there are financial interests out there, all around the world, that don't like the idea of the Neutrality Fleet.
They want their home countries, and their commercial interests, to have protection that's loyal to their own interests and answerable to no one else.
So you have people able to pay to have civilian ships refitted for combat, and you have people eager to crew those ships. Hence, volunteer fleets.
And... you don't approve?

Fields.MenuText: Depends on the ships and crews we're talking about.

Fields.DialogueText: Right now, I think we're talking about one of the good ones. The Jolly Thresher is an American ship based out of Florida, and they've got some kind of arrangement with the Navy.
They've been supplementing our efforts to protect commercial traffic along the Brazilian coast.
Except that they've disappeared with all hands.
What? Disappeared? You mean a Morgana sank her.
Most likely, but nobody witnessed it. Ever since her disappearance, other freighters passing through the area have been being picked off at an alarming rate.
The Morganas killed the guard dog, and now they're foxes in the henhouse.
Exactly. We've been assigned to guarding the coast, deterring the Morganas... and searching for any signs of the Jolly Thresher.
... I know the Thresher, I think. One of the Hog Islanders, maybe? Or at least based on the EFC 1022. We only passed once or twice, but she seemed nice.
What was her captain's name?
Captain Moriah Jones. The U.S. Navy is still a little bit uneasy about female captains, but everything they've told me about her is pretty impressive.
I remember her! She had a clever tongue. Not a remarkably incredible commander, but a brave one.
She was a captain who deserved respect .... if the Morganas sank the Thresher, she would go down with her ship.
But it's possible there may be other survivors.
That's true. We should... Captain! Look, over the bow! It looks like the Morganas are coming right to us now, ha!
It is convenient that we don't even have to leave port to find them. But we need to draw them away from the base.
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: The last thing we need is civilians playing pirate.
It's an admirable cause. The least we can do is provide material support and advice.

Fields.DialogueText: There's plenty that don't have any idea what they're up against, for sure.
Against the volunteers, the Morganas are usually the safe bet.
Where it's bound to be useful, sure.
Enterprise! What are you doing down here? Didn't you notice the Morgana cruisers your RDF picked up?
Uhh... what? Oh! Oh, yes, of course! I'll be on the bridge in a moment, Captain!
@BATTLE
What are you doing down here in the kitchens again, Enterprise? The battle is barely over!
... Nothing, Captain!
... It smells like something is on fire.
It's not! ... Well, at least it isn't... anymore....
Enterprise! You know how dangerous fire can be on a ship!
Don't lecture me! I am this ship, Captain! Besides, it wasn't really on fire, I just... burned it a bit...
What is that supposed to be?
... Well, it was going to be feijoada. If it weren't for those damn Morganas, it would have been feijoada!
Woah, calm down. You can try again, can't you?
I don't have enough of the right kind of sausage and spices to try it again. And... and I'll be honest, Captain... I'm not a very good cook.

Fields.MenuText: We can buy more supplies next time we make port, and I can help you cook.
Don't worry, I'll buy you some feijoada next time we're in port.
It's good to know one's weaknesses.

Fields.DialogueText: ... You know how to cook, Captain? Well... I suppose your help can't exactly hurt.
I don't want to bother you to buy me treats, Captain, especially in times like these. I can do this for myself!
Not the best pep talk I've ever had, Captain.
Ugh. I suppose I should give it up for today. I think this pot is beyond repair. Hopefully I don't get written up for destruction of naval property.
What are you looking at, Enterprise?
The records of Captain Jones' last transmissions to the base in Natal... and I'm sorting through her transmission to other ships with Belles in those last few days before she went missing.
How did you get the records of that?
We Belles have our ways of communicating. This... is not the most thrilling thing I've ever done, but it's important. We can't let a whole ship go MIA.
Hmm. She last made contact with the Natal Navy base at oh-eight-hundred hours, a week ago, off the coast of Rio de Janeiro.
She must have been set upon by Morganas and sunk... but the Jolly Thresher had just won a battle, against a Morgana light cruiser. Her last communications are a report of that fight.
Speaking of fight, Captain, I think Morganas are coming to save me from this drudgery.
@BATTLE
Damn! Crap! Damn, damn, damn!
... We won, Enterprise.
"We won." I don't count it as winning when the Airedales take that kind of pounding!

Fields.MenuText: I know how you feel, but it is a victory nonetheless. The Morganas suffered worse.
... I know how you feel. It doesn't feel like a victory.
Pull yourself together, Enterprise!

Fields.DialogueText: ... That's true. But can Morganas even suffer, truly? Somehow I don't think so.
No. It doesn't.
No, Captain! Not when I just saw those men get torn apart, when I could have done something to stop it! I felt them die, Captain! I've felt every person on this ship who...
... Sorry. I'm... tired. I let my emotions get away from me. We should examine the Jolly Thresher's communications some more, Captain.
After you rest, Enterprise.
She was reporting casualties, Captain.
What?
The last transmission from the Jolly Thresher's captain. She was reporting the casualties her crew suffered in battle against a Morgana aircraft carrier.
Hmmm. Perhaps that aircraft carrier called in backup. If the Jolly Thresher was damaged, she could have easily been overwhelmed by a Morgana or two.

Fields.MenuText: She had nowhere near the firepower of your aircraft.

Fields.DialogueText: That's true. We're approaching her last known coordinates...
Are you picking up anything, Enterprise?
No, Captain. Wait! There's something to starboard... moving towards us...
The Jolly Thresher?
... No. It's Morganas!
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: If I know anything about her, it's that she's tenacious. She just might have pulled through.
They shouldn't have been out there in the first place.

Fields.DialogueText: I want to believe you, Captain. Let me see... we should almost be to her last known coordinates.
Easy for us to say, Captain. We should stick to the search. Hmm... hold on.
Your arguments with Miss Adele are beginning to be something of a disruption, Enterprise.
Okay, yeah, but... it's not like I'm being unreasonable, right?
I wouldn't have to argue with her if she didn't insist on trying to peddle me as some sort of sex symbol.

Fields.MenuText: I understand your frustrations. I'll try to get her assigned elsewhere.
Surely she must have some pictures by now. She'll move on soon.
For God's sake, Enterprise, just let her take the pictures.

Fields.DialogueText: Good. Thank you, Captain. I never want to see her silly face again.
You would think, but I'm not sure she's taken a single picture. She's spent all her time waving her finger in my face and lecturing me on fashion.
Whatever pictures she takes will introduce me to the American public, Captain!
I know it may seem trivial or stupid to you, but how do we remember my predecessors? By fragments, by things like the banner I wear on my belt.
You're afraid of these pictures becoming what your descendents see of you?
It's not just that. My legacy is important to me, but... it's also... how can she make light of this?
How can she ask me to put on makeup and blush and simper for her camera when I'm the soul of a fighting ship?
My crew, my captain, and I... we risk our lives for my country. That can't be boiled down to a few awkward smiles. That's not what Belles are, or should be.
... You certainly are impassioned.
It's... Captain! There's a Morgana on my RDF!
No doubt one of those preying on Brazilian merchant ships.
@BATTLE
Excellent, Captain! We beat her bloody! It will be a long time before she tries these shores again.
Hmm. Thank you, Enterprise. ... Why are you smiling like that? That look in your eye isn't just victory...
I know what I'm going to do with Miss Adele. She should shoot up here, during our next fight! Then the pictures would reflect the work us Belles really do.
Interesting idea, Enterprise.
Who knows? Maybe I'll get really lucky and spook her off the battlefield.
And the dolphins were pink! And my captain swore up and down his first mate was lying, until...
Enterprise! Can I have a word with you? If I may borrow our Belle, gentlemen...
Of course, Captain!
An odd collection of crewmen you had there, Enterprise. You don't usually see such a mix, even in the mess.
Hah, they're my American crew. Some of them have been with me even longer than you. A few of them sailed with me on my shakedown cruise, actually.
Ah, of course. Showing a bit of favoritism, are you?
Hah! No, no. We just like to gather together sometimes, swap stories...
I care for all my crew a great deal, but bonds of country are rather like ties of kinship. They run deep. Is that a jealous look, Captain?

Fields.MenuText: Of course not. I'm your captain; you chose me. What bond could run deeper than that?
You chose me to captain you. Choice matters more than an accident of blood or birth.
Why would I be jealous? I share the same bond with you, and more.

Fields.DialogueText: That's true. We're blood brothers, you and I. Er... well, maybe that's not the right phrase. But we're something close.
You forget, Captain: I'm a construct of intent, not an accident. But I agree in this instance. My bond with you... it runs deeper than most.
Of course! We could be blood brothers, even. So to speak.
Did any of those you were talking to have any experience with Captain Jones?
A few. They all got the impression she was an upstanding, brave captain, and her death is a tragedy. Why?
I was just curious. I think we'll make port at Rio de Janeiro for a time. I'd like to see if anyone saw anything the day the Jolly Thresher disappeared.
We'll have to work for it, Captain. We've got Morganas looking to disappear us!
@BATTLE
Oh are you a pirate or a man o'war he cried? A-sailing down along the coast of High Barbary!
Still have that song stuck in your head?
Captain! Did you find anything of interest in Rio de Janeiro?
That depends on how you define "of interest."
Was there any word of the Jolly Thresher? Did anyone see her sink? Did you get me any feijoada?
I spoke with some Brazilian naval officers from the Arsenal de Marinha do Rio de Janeiro.
Most of them had met or worked with Captain Jones and thought her an honest, trustworthy woman.
But none of them knew anything about her disappearance?
No. They've had their hands full defending the coast for quite some time, and Captain Jones' disappearance hardly helped matters.
The Morganas are getting bolder, apparently.
Why wouldn't they? This coast is rich with resources, and it's hardly the most well-guarded by the fleet. Ugh, I hate sitting here and waiting! I feel useless.

Fields.MenuText: I understand. It's difficult for someone like you to be shut out from the action.
We'll be back out there and fighting again soon enough.
Patience is a virtue, Enterprise. We won't help anyone by charging out there again.

Fields.DialogueText: I just hate being useless, Captain. I hate uncertainty. I want to help Captain Jones, but... honestly I think the odds are good she's dead. And I can't do anything about it.
Is that enough, though? Will it ever be enough? We bounce from fight to fight... I'm so afraid we're not really helping anyone.
I know that! That doesn't mean that sitting in port like this with circumstances being what they are doesn't salt my engines!
Captain... the Morganas down here certainly are bold! There's one approaching the port. No, a few of them.
This is a well-defended port, but we've got to get out there. We can't let this turn into another incident like the shipyard.
@BATTLE
Enterprise, I saw you talking to those fishermen on the docks after the attack on Rio de Janeiro. I don't think I've seen you off the ship before.
I can't step far onto land, Cap. Or far away from my ship, I mean, but I could call those fishermen closer to me. They were quite willing to talk, after they saw us help defend the city.
What did they say? Anything of interest?
Enterprise? What's wrong?
They were drunk, and foolish. They didn't know what they saw. They probably thought I was some young, gullible naval officer whose ears they could fill with tall tales.
... Enterprise?
And my Portuguese is hardly what it used to be, it was hardly enough for pleasantries at the... damn. Captain, I'm just trying to fool myself.
What did they say?
They witnessed the sinking of a freighter, one of those assumed to be sunk by Morganas.
They say she was sunk by a ragged ship flying no flag... but painted in American colors.
... Do you mean to say they think Captain Jones has been sinking Brazilian freighters?
I don't know what to think. It doesn't make sense. Why would she cut contact and abandon her duty, to turn and do the Morganas' work for them?

Fields.MenuText: It couldn't be her. The Morganas could have incorporated parts of her hull into their repairs, or...
Maybe there was a mutiny aboard the Jolly Thresher.
Plenty of people turn traitor, Enterprise. It's a fact of war.

Fields.DialogueText: That's true.
I doubt it. The Jolly Thresher's crew had yet to be reassigned by the Fleet. She was still sailing with her original American crew. None of them would be likely to mutiny.
... I know. I just... I don't know. I'm lost.
Captain Jones wouldn't turn against the people she was set to protect. No captain would.
We'll figure this out, Enterprise.
Ugh. If we ever get time to think.
@BATTLE
Captain! Come look at this! Quickly!
What is it, Enterprise? Is there a Morgana... what are those?
Gaviotas! Also called frigate birds, or man o' war birds. They're similar to albatrosses.
Hopefully they don't carry the same ill omens.
They don't! They're similar to the American bald eagle, in a way. They symbolize freedom in some places. And they're seen as good omens, signalling land is near.
I wouldn't advise trying to hurt one. They can be fierce! I remember watching them on my first cruise... they're a mean species, but beautiful.
One of my crew whittled me a little carving of one, last time we were here... he was the one who gave me the idea to start carving my airplanes.
Does every trinket on your belt tell a story?
Hah, well, not stories exactly. Most of them are pretty uninteresting, like that one. But it's like... a journal of where I'm from, and where I've been.
Tokens of your predecessors... your aircraft... your navy crest...
This is a Virginia rose, for my home... this is a piece of the metal that was forged into my torpedo blister...
That reminds me. I... I'd like to add something that represents you, at some point. You're another important thing in my travels.

Fields.MenuText: I would be honored, Enterprise. I'd have to think of what that could be...
I don't know what could represent me.
I'm a thing, am I?

Fields.DialogueText: Ah, thank you, Captain! Take your time, there's no rush.
It's hard to sum up anything in just an object... but it's more a momento than anything else. It doesn't have to have obvious meaning.
You know what I mean, Cap!
Well, I'll consider it. In the meantime--
In the meantime, Morganas are trying to get by us to the coast!
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Almost in range...
I just hope we can start shooting before any Morganas try talking to us. Ugh.
@BATTLE
Well, I suppose Miss Adele simply doesn't have the fortitude of soul to photograph a Belle in her natural environment.
Did you see how fast she bolted when the bullets and shells started flying?

Fields.MenuText: She did do a credible impression of a spooked deer.
That would be anyone's reaction when faced with their first head-on fight.
Don't be so rude, Enterprise. No one is brave when first facing down machine guns and enemy aircraft.

Fields.DialogueText: Hah, she did! With her skirts fluttering and her eyes rolling... not a woman suited for life on the sea. I wondered how she had been faring, shut up in her cabin during the fights.
It certainly wasn't mine! Making a blatant statement like that erases the bravery of the real seamen we have onboard, Captain, who face battles despite their fear.
No one may be brave, but everyone must do their duty. She failed at that.
Now she wants me back into that cabin of hers, posing with rouge-smudged cheeks and a come-hither smile. Ugh!
No one will be forcing you to do anything, Enterprise. She's not in the chain of command.
I just wish she could see the real work we Belles do...
Captain! My RDF is picking up two unknown ships!
Morganas?
Maybe... Look! There, on the horizon! That... that looks like... that's the Jolly Thresher!
What?! Give me those binoculars... It is the Jolly Thresher! What's that other craft? It doesn't look like a Morgana.
... No. It looks like a freighter. It's flying the Brazilian flag. ... That flash! She's... she's firing on the freighter.

Fields.MenuText: Her crew must have some reason for it.
This must be some misunderstanding...
So what they said was right. She has turned pirate.

Fields.DialogueText: They must! I know Captain Jones wouldn't turn on the people she was supposed to protect!
Of course. It seems difficult, but perhaps she mistook the merchant for a Morgana...
... She can't have. Captain Jones wouldn't do that. No American captain would.
We've got to hail her! Establish communications and figure out what the hell is going on!
She sees us. She's turning around... she's going to flee!
Enterprise, look! To port! Morganas on course to the freighter...
Morganas can wait. We've got to go after the Thresher!
That freighter is a sitting duck. Our job is to defend the coast and the ships that call it home... that's the job that the Thresher clearly has deserted!
... You're right, Captain. Of course. We can hunt down the Thresher, no matter where she runs.
@BATTLE
Captain! There she is! The Thresher! Hah, I knew we would catch up to her!
*static*... Come in, Enterprise.
That frequency is coming from the Thresher! That's... that's Captain Jones' voice! I'd recognize it anywhere. She's trying to hail us!
Mr. Pelir, let me handle this. I...
What the have you done, Captain Jones? What are you doing?
*static*... voice that young can't be a captain... *static*... assume I'm speaking with a Belle?
A Belle and her captain, Captain Jones. You've done a lot you have to answer for. It would be best if you surrendered yourself and your ship to our custody.
Traitor! How could you do this?
*static* ...not likely... *static* ... the circumstances. To be stranded out here, fighting nightmares come to life day after day without a word from... *static*
We've been given the same job, Jones. Me, and my captain, and my crew have faced the same that yours have without ever wavering! You and yours are cowards!
Enterprise! Look! There's a Morgana approaching. She looks intent on us... and she brought friends.
Damn! We've got to fight her...
@BATTLE
The Thresher has fled...
Coward! Yellow-bellied, miserable turncoat! I hope she drowns!
Enterprise?
Oh... hi, Captain.
You've been out here on deck for hours.
We've got to catch her, Captain. I have to know why she abandoned her duty.

Fields.MenuText: We will, Enterprise. I know we will.
She's just one ship, with one crew. Why does it matter so much?
If we don't get her, the Morganas will.

Fields.DialogueText: We have to. We have to, Captain. She's our own... my own... and she betrayed her duty!
She betrayed her duty. In a war where all of us have put aside our differences to fight together, she is shirking and pirating. Nothing could be more cowardly.
I hope she rots, but she would only feed the Morganas. We have to get to her first.
There's ships on my RDF! It's... no. It's just Morganas. Come on, we've got to get rid of them!
@BATTLE
Enterprise, stop firing the guns! The Morganas have fled, and you're scaring the men!
How could she do this? How could she betray our country like this? How could she abuse her power? We're supposed to be above that!
Are you talking about the Jolly Thresher, or Captain Jones?
Both. Either. I don't know.
I know the Thresher doesn't have a choice like you do, Enterprise.
I... I don't really have a choice, do I, Captain? I chose you, but I'm bound to your orders. I could fight... I could fight it, but in the end, I would have to do as you said.
I would never betray the fleet. Or you. Don't you know that?
...I want to, Captain. I want to.
*ALARM*
Here she comes!
I'm ready if you are, Captain.
You know I am.
@BATTLE
Excellent battle, Enterprise. Now, about our earlier conversation...

Fields.MenuText: I'm sorry if I've ever given you reason to doubt me, Enterprise.
I would never abuse my position as Captain to betray you.
After all we have been through, I don't understand why the thought would cross your mind.

Fields.DialogueText: ... You haven't, Captain.
... I know, Captain.
... I don't know why it did, Captain.
It feels like the sea has shifted under my hull. I don't understand how someone like Jones could betray the Fleet and her country. I thought people like her were above things like that.
I see. And me?
... I know. I overreacted, Captain. I'm sorry. You're my dearest friend, you know that.
You seemed to doubt it.
... I don't, Captain. I promise. I'm sorry. I'm really, really sorry.
Ouch, Enterprise, you don't have to squeeze so hard when you hug. I forget how strong you really are.
I'm sorry, Captain. I... I won't let myself doubt you again.
There's the Thresher.
It looks like she took a hit from a Morgana in the last fight - look how she's listing slightly in the water.
All hands to stations! Better she be safe at the bottom of the sea than killing innocents!

Fields.MenuText: Of course. All hands to stations!
That's my order to give, Enterprise. Don't steal my lines.
The fleet needs all the ships it can get. We should try to capture her intact.

Fields.DialogueText: Let's blow her to pieces, Captain!
Hah, of course. I don't mean to imply mutiny, Captain!
The fleet doesn't need an old wreck! We should make an example of her!
... What? We're being hailed again, Enterprise.
... I don't want to talk to her.
*static* understand, Enterprise... *static*
What do you have to say for yourself, traitor? Why have you and your men turned coat when so many have fought and died without complaint?
You wouldn't... *static* know what it's like, at the mercy of those creatures... *static* ships torn apart, men and animals subject to *static* the things we've seen would...
With hardly a word of advice from the government, just vague... *static* about research and progress made... *static* my crew die in droves to those creatures...
... *static* haven't managed to sink one, Enterprise! Not one Morgana!
When will the conflict end? Was I to sail here forever, prolonging the lives of ... *static* and fishermen until the world crumbles to their onslaught?
Yes! That's your job! We're supposed to protect the world, Captain Jones!
You're.... *static*.
She's turning to escape! We have to sink her!
Look at your RDF. There's Morganas...
Damn! How can one traitor have so much luck?
@BATTLE
What was that melodramatic display, Enterprise?
... I don't like that woman. I want her off my decks! We're going to drop her off at the naval base in Natal and no doubt the brass there can find her a sultry Belle to photograph.
Enterprise...
Or maybe she can talk a Morgana into being her muse. She's certainly got a mouth to do that.
I think she'd find that effort wasted, since you broke her camera.
Oh, don't give me that accusing look, Captain! I barely scratched the damn thing.
You grabbed it from her hands and threw it. In full view of half the crew.
Get me some names and I can pull an encore for the other half!
You're not acting like yourself, Enterprise. You're worrying me.
Oh, stop it! Stop acting like you know every little thing about me! I'm just angry Miss Adele can't see the plain truth in front of her face.
She's so desperate to fit reality to her ideas!
She knows full well what happened here, who we're after, and still she's trying to find the right picture to sell the glorious patriotism of the Navy to the American public!
It's... it's infuriating!

Fields.MenuText: It's wrong, but it is her job. She's following her orders.
But it's not like it's disinformation. In her ham-fisted way she's trying to show the American public that the Belles are different than the Morganas. You can respect the goal, if not the approach.
Propaganda is what funds the fleet, Enterprise.

Fields.DialogueText: ... No one should follow orders blindly, Cap.
I don't have to respect anything! We're fighting the monsters! That should speak for itself, even if I'm not batting my eyes at the camera.
It's lies, and I want no part in it.
I just... I just... I don't understand. I... I thought... I-I didn't think anyone could... We're supposed to be the world's protectors!
But that's... that's just another bit of propaganda, isn't it? Like Miss Adele's stupid pictures.
... Captain Jones proves that.
Enterprise, Captain Jones is just one...
I'm picking up Morganas on my RDF, Captain. To port... There! Look! They're attacking another ship!
We'll talk later. We might be able to save that ship, or at least those onboard.
@BATTLE
Did you read the decoded TBS message from Brass about the Thresher?
Of course. It didn't surprise me. It makes sense the U.S. wants to keep Captain Jones' defection quiet. Nobody wants to see the volunteer fleet business fall apart or go underground.
Or they just want to avoid embarrassment.
We're the only major power not suffering a land war. We should be the tip of the spear against the Morganas, not... this.

Fields.MenuText: I don't think the flaws of one captain and one crew can reflect an entire nation.
Maybe it's partially that land wars are really good at focusing a nation's attention. The U.S. will catch up.
You're right. Captain Jones has disgraced the whole country.

Fields.DialogueText: Captain Jones' actions are so heinous that they certainly could, at least in the eyes of the public. She's been hunting the people she was supposed to protect!
Maybe you're right. Still, there are plenty of foreign captains and crews who are new to war and don't lie down and roll over and turn traitor at the first sign of a fight!
We have to bring her in, Captain, or sink her. Soon, before she sinks any more Brazilian ships or causes any more grief!
We're going to have to find her alone. The fleet wants this dealt with quietly, if we can. They fear spreading the word of Jones's betrayal will encourage others to do the same.
Do they really think they have such cowardly captains? I hope they're wrong, for all our sakes. But we're perfectly capable of hunting down one cruiser...
... Just as we're perfectly capable of dealing with the Morganas off starboard!
@BATTLE
You don't need to give me a lecture, Captain. I know I went too far with the crew today.
You did. I know everyone is used to your criticisms being harsh when needed, but always good-natured. That... was not good-natured.
I lost my temper. I'm sorry. I really am. This hunt, this whole ordeal with the Thresher... it's been hard for me.
I know. The crew knows that, too. But...

Fields.MenuText: You're their superior, and it's not fair to take out your anger on them.
You're their Belle. You've got to put on a brave face for their sake.
You need to get a hold of yourself.

Fields.DialogueText: I know. I know. I'm sorry, Cap. I won't let it happen again.
It's hard being a Belle, sometimes, Cap. But I won't let it happen again. I promise.
... I know. I know, I'm sorry, I'm sorry.
Taking out my feelings on the crew is cowardly in its own way...
I'm here for you, Enterprise.
I know. I should have come and talked to you about all of this. I just... I don't know. I'm not dealing with this particularly well, am I? I'm always so good at handling stress...
This is a bit more than stress. But I see you've found one companion to cheer you up, anyway.
Hah, the cat? Cap is a good cat.
Remind me why you named the cat that...
Because it's funny!
... I know it's not my best joke. Captain, I guess I can understand Jones abandoning her duty. We've all been tired and in despair, however briefly.
But... how can she turn on those who she was supposed to help? How many others would do the same, if given the opportunity?
One bad captain doesn't make the rest traitors, you know. We humans have a great deal of free will when it comes to things like that.
Some of us can be fickle. I think... loyalty may be a degree different for Belles.
We're built to be loyal, Captain. To the end.
Not all humans are like that. Not all humans have the capability to be like that. But many are strong, and loyal.
Like you, Captain. I... I know. I can't expect the same things from people as I can expect from Belles.
That's hard to remember sometimes... but I know most of our captains are good, and loyal. I've got to believe that. It's why I picked you.
I'm glad you did, Enterprise. Let's prove you right again.
Damn, they're really getting sneaky! All right, pilots, wheels up!
@BATTLE
There she is! The Thresher!
She's still limping along. She can't escape from us!
Come in, Enterprise.
What have you got to say for yourself, Jones?
Keep her talking. It may distract her.
You're going to face your superiors and your nation, and the whole world will see you for the traitor you are!
Killing those you were sworn to protect, disobeying your most basic orders, running like a coward from the fight and seeking out easy targets!
*static* ... did what I had to do, Belle. You haven't sailed these seas for as long as I have. You can't understand. My first priority is to protect my crew, and... *static*.
Your first priority was to protect the world from Morganas, Captain!
... *static* foreign shores. America didn't need to... *static* my men dying for the sake of them. Have you seen what the Morganas do to men, Enterprise?

Fields.MenuText: You can't excuse your treachery and piracy, Captain Jones.
What do the Morganas do to men?
Enough talking. Surrender your ship or we'll blow you to pieces.

Fields.DialogueText: My captain is right! You're nothing more than a deserter and a pirate!
They kill them. We all die, Captain. We can't turn traitor for fear of that!
For the sake of your ship and crew, Captain Jones, surrender.
... *static* too late.
Captain, my RDF is picking up something approaching... look! Behind the Thresher! That's an airplane!
And there's the aircraft carrier. It looks like Sin.
Those airplanes aren't heading for us...
I guess the Thresher is easier prey this time. We've got to fight her off.
The Thresher is ablaze!
@BATTLE
... *static* Enterprise... *static* help... *static*.
She's sinking... without us firing a shot.
We did all we could.
... Damn it. No, Captain, no we didn't. I'm taking us closer.
A sailing down along the coast of High Barbary... for quarters, for quarters, the saucy pirate cried...
You didn't have to risk your life for traitors, Enterprise.
Oh! Sorry, you startled me, Captain. I still can't get this song out of my head...
For a Belle, being in the water isn't much of a risk, Captain. We're built for it, after all!
I couldn't really do much, but I managed to get a few of the Thresher's crew closest to my ship to the lifeboats.

Fields.MenuText: That was very brave, Enterprise. You should be commended for your mercy.
Good job. It's common courtesy. Now they can be put to trial.
You should have let the traitors drown.

Fields.DialogueText: It isn't mercy, Captain. The navy will try and imprison them, or maybe even execute them.
Exactly. That is how it should be.
They will be put to trial, Captain, and won't escape punishment for their deeds. I didn't do them any favors.
Did the crew of the lifeboats find Captain Jones?
No. I have a few groups still looking, but it's likely she went down with the Jolly Thresher.
I knew Captain Jones would... poor ship. She didn't deserve a captain like that.
The quarters that we gave them was to sink them in the tide...
I think I hate this song, Captain.
I don't think anyone onboard is very fond of it, at this point.
We won, Captain. In name, at least. The Morganas did our work for us... I don't feel proud. I don't know if I would feel proud even if we had sunk the Thresher ourselves.
We did what was necessary to protect Brazil. The coasts will be safer, now. Plus, we dealt another blow to Sin.
Hah, that's true! I bet she's grinding her teeth over that. She just can't seem to win when I'm involved, no matter how many times she tries to sink me!
She shouldn't have tried to destroy my hometown - I'll keep haunting her!
We did good, Enterprise.
I guess we did.
But the work isn't over just yet. I got word of Morganas heading towards the coast to the east of here. Do you think the crew can handle another fight?
Definitely!
@BATTLE
Did Miss Adele get the photos she wanted at the party?
Hah, I suppose she must have. She looked quite pleased that she managed to wrangle me into formal attire... though I think she would have been more pleased had I worn a dress.
I think a naval dress uniform suits you. It should be enough for her.
... She showed me some other pictures she took, too. On the day the Jolly Thresher sunk. I... I think those capture me best, to be honest. I don't know if she'll end up using them.
I suppose I'll trust her judgment. I still feel bad about damaging her camera, but I'm glad we were able to fix it... I think she'll turn out some good publicity.
You're being uncharacteristically kind to her, Enterprise. How much did you have to drink?
... the head of the Brazilian Expeditionary Force may have given me some very good cachaça... but don't worry, it was only a small bottle.
Where were you, though? Some admiral was looking for you later on... I think he walked the length of my decks ten times over.
I stepped out for a bit, sorry. It took longer than I thought it would to find this at a restaurant in the city...
Feijoada! Captain! You didn't!
I figured it was only fair, after you had been denied it at every turn.
Thank you! Hah, you certainly know how to make a Belle happy, Captain.
I know how to make you happy, at least. It usually isn't very hard, luckily.
What can I say? I'm a girl of simple tastes, my friend.
I have something else for you, as well.
What is it?!
I know you wanted something from me to add to your trinket belt...

Fields.MenuText: I wanted something to remind you of your own freedom, and the fact my home is with you.
... You did name that damn cat after me.
I wanted to remind you of my promise. When others abandon their duties, I won't. We will succeed together.

Fields.DialogueText: A frigate bird! ... An omen that land, and home, is near. You... you really regard me as home? As... as family?
A wooden cat! Hah, did you carve this yourself? Aw... thank you, Captain.
A scrap of wood... this... this is a piece of the Thresher. I... I understand, Captain. You will never do to me what Captain Jones did to the Thresher.
... Choosing you as my captain was the best decision I ever made, Captain. You're the best friend I've ever had.
I feel the same, Enterprise.
A good captain, and good feijoada... I really am a lucky Belle.
